revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = | image = File:Debra Messing July 13 2014 cropped and lighting corrected.jpg | caption = Messing in July 2014 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1968|8|15}} | birth_name = Debra Lynn Messing | birth_place = [[Brooklyn]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. | spouse = {{marriage|[[Daniel Zelman]]|2000|2016|reason=divorced}} | children = 1 | occupation = Actress | alma_mater = [[Brandeis University]]
[[New York University]] | years_active = 1994–present }} '''Debra Lynn Messing''' (born August 15, 1968) is an American actress. After graduating from [[New York University]]'s [[Tisch School of the Arts]], Messing received short-lived roles on television series such as ''[[Ned & Stacey]]'' on [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] (1995–1997) and ''[[Prey (TV series)|Prey]]'' on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] (1998). She achieved her breakthrough role as [[Grace Adler]], an interior designer, on the [[NBC]] sitcom ''[[Will & Grace]]'' (1998–2006/2017-), for which she was critically acclaimed, receiving six [[Golden Globe Award]] nominations and five [[Primetime Emmy Award]] nominations for [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actress in a Comedy Series|Outstanding Lead Actress in a Comedy Series]], winning once in 2003. From 2007 to 2008, Messing starred as Molly Kagan, the ex-wife of a Hollywood film mogul, on the television miniseries ''[[The Starter Wife (TV series)|The Starter Wife]]'', for which she received two Golden Globe nominations, a Primetime Emmy Award nomination and a [[Screen Actors Guild Award]] nomination for her performance. Thereafter, she appeared as Broadway playwright Julia Houston on the NBC musical drama ''[[Smash (TV series)|Smash]]'' (2012–2013) and as homicide detective Laura Diamond on the NBC police-procedural comedy ''[[The Mysteries of Laura]]'' (2014–2016). Since 2017, Messing has been reprising her role as Grace Adler on NBC's revival of ''Will & Grace''. Messing's film work includes ''[[A Walk in the Clouds]]'' (1995), ''[[Jesus (1999 film)|Jesus]]'' (1999), ''[[The Mothman Prophecies (film)|The Mothman Prophecies]]'' (2002), ''[[Hollywood Ending]]'' (2002), ''[[Along Came Polly]]'' (2004), ''[[The Wedding Date]]'' (2005), ''[[Lucky You (film)|Lucky You]]'' (2007), ''[[The Women (2008 film)|The Women]]'' (2008), ''[[Nothing like the Holidays]]'' (2008), and ''[[Searching (film)|Searching]]'' (2018). She has also lent her voice to animated films such as ''[[Garfield (film)|Garfield]]'' (2004) and ''[[Open Season (2006 film)|Open Season]]'' (2006). ==Early life== Messing was born in the [[Brooklyn]] borough of [[New York City]],Stated in interview on ''[[Inside the Actors Studio]]''{{cite web|first=Richard |last=Ouzounian|url=http://www.toronto.com/article/716250--debra-messing-in-smash |title=Debra Messing in Smash |work=[[The Toronto Star]] |publisher=Toronto Star Newspapers Ltd.|location=Toronto, Ontario, Canada|date=March 9, 2012 |accessdate=March 9, 2012||dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130205084722/http://www.toronto.com/article/716250--debra-messing-in-smash|archive-date=February 5, 2013 }} the daughter of Sandra ([[married and maiden names|née]] Simons), who worked as a professional [[singer]], [[banker]], [[Travel Agent|travel]] and [[real estate agent]], and Brian Messing, a sales executive for a costume jewelry packaging manufacturer.{{cite web|url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/56/Debra-Messing.html |title=Debra Messing Biography (1968-) |publisher=Filmreference.com |date= |accessdate=April 7, 2010}} Messing is [[Jews|Jewish]], and had a [[Bar and Bat Mitzvah|Bat Mitzvah]] ceremony; her Jewish ancestors emigrated from Poland and Russia.{{cite web|url=http://www.atlantajewish.com/content/032006/messing.html |title=American Jewish Life Magazine |publisher=Atlantajewish.com |date= |accessdate=2010-04-07}}{{cite web|first=Naomi |last=Pfefferman |url=http://www.jewishjournal.com/home/preview.php?id=8506 |title=JewishJournal.com |publisher=JewishJournal.com |date=2002-05-02 |accessdate=2010-04-07}}{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20137029,00.html |title=Debra Messing: Actress - Most Beautiful, Debra Messing |publisher=People.com |date=2002-05-13 |accessdate=2010-04-07}} When Messing was three, she moved with her parents and her older brother, Brett, to [[East Greenwich, Rhode Island]].{{cite news|last=Williams|first=Jeannie|title= Debra Messing yells 'Hooray!' for 'Hollywood'|pages=|publisher=USA Today|date=2002-05-03|url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/movies/2002/2002-05-03-messing.htm|accessdate=2007-12-09}} During her [[high school]] years, she acted and sang in a number of high school productions at [[East Greenwich High School]], including the starring roles in the musicals ''[[Annie (musical)|Annie]]'' and ''[[Grease (musical)|Grease]]''. She took lessons in dance, singing, and acting. In 1986, she was [[Rhode Island]]'s Junior Miss and competed in [[Mobile, Alabama]], in the [[America's Junior Miss]] scholarship program. While her parents encouraged her dream of becoming an actress, they also urged her to complete a [[liberal arts]] education before deciding on acting as a career. Following their advice, she attended [[Brandeis University]], where at her parents' request, three quarters of her courses were not theater related. During her junior year, she studied theater at the prestigious [[United Kingdom|British]] European Studies Group of [[London]] (BESGL) program, an experience that solidified her desire to act. In 1990, after graduating ''[[Latin honors|summa cum laude]]'' from Brandeis with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] in Theater Arts, Messing gained admission to the elite [[Tisch School of the Arts#Graduate Acting Program|Graduate Acting Program]] at [[New York University]]'s [[Tisch School of the Arts]], which accepts about 15 new students annually. She earned a [[Master of Fine Arts]] after three years.{{cite web | author= | title=NYU Graduate Acting Alumni | url=http://gradacting.tisch.nyu.edu/object/ga_alumbios.html | year=2011 | accessdate=2011-12-01}} ==Career== In 1993, Messing won acclaim for her performance as Harper in the pre-[[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] workshop production of [[Tony Kushner]]'s play ''[[Angels in America: Perestroika]]''. Subsequently, she appeared in several episodes of the television series ''[[NYPD Blue]]'' during 1994 and 1995. [[File:Debra Messing (April 2009) 4.jpg|thumb|left| Messing at the [[Tribeca Film Festival]] 2009 premiere of ''[[Whatever Works]]'']] In 1995, Messing made her film debut in [[Alfonso Arau]]'s ''[[A Walk in the Clouds]]'' playing the unfaithful wife of main character Paul Sutton ([[Keanu Reeves]]). This exposure led the [[Fox network]] to make her the co-star of the television sitcom, ''[[Ned & Stacey]]''. The series lasted for two seasons, from 1995 to 1997. Messing appeared as [[Jerry Seinfeld (character)|Jerry Seinfeld]]'s romantic interest in two episodes of the series ''[[Seinfeld]]'': "[[The Wait Out]]" in 1996 and "[[The Yada Yada]]" in 1997. Messing turned down a starring role in another television sitcom to appear in [[Donald Margulies]]'s two-character play ''Collected Stories'', which opened at the [[off-Broadway]] Manhattan Theater Club. She also co-starred in the [[Tom Arnold (actor)|Tom Arnold]] vehicle ''[[McHale's Navy (1997 film)|McHale's Navy]]'' in 1997. In 1998, Messing played a lead role as the [[bioanthropology|bioanthropologist]] Sloan Parker on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]'s dramatic [[science fiction]] television series ''[[Prey (TV series)|Prey]]''. During this time, her agent approached her with the pilot script for the television show ''[[Will & Grace]]''. Messing was inclined to take some time off, but the script intrigued her, and she auditioned for the role of [[Grace Adler]], beating out [[Nicollette Sheridan]], who later guest-starred on the show as Grace's romantic rival. ''Will & Grace'' became a ratings success, and Messing became a star. In 2002, she was named one of the "50 Most Beautiful People in the World" by ''[[People Magazine|People]]''. ''[[TV Guide]]'' picked her as its "Best Dressed Woman" in 2003. And Messing's trademark curls on ''Will & Grace'' won her five Crown Awards from voters at the celebrity hair site Super-Hair.Net between 2000 and 2008. Messing was cast by director [[Woody Allen]] in a small role in his 2002 film ''[[Hollywood Ending]]''. Her film roles since include [[Richard Gere]]'s ill-fated wife in the supernatural thriller ''[[The Mothman Prophecies (film)|The Mothman Prophecies]]'' (2002) and a supporting role as an unfaithful bride in ''[[Along Came Polly]]'' (2004). ''[[The Wedding Date]]'' (2005) was Messing's first leading role in a high-profile film. It received mixed reviews, but performed fairly well at the box office. Messing was featured as a judge on the season finale of the second season of [[Bravo (US TV channel)|Bravo]]'s [[reality show]], ''[[Project Runway]]''. Also in 2005, along with [[Megan Mullally]], she was awarded the [[Women in Film Los Angeles|Women in Film]] [[Women in Film Crystal + Lucy Awards#THE LUCY AWARD|Lucy Award]] in recognition of her excellence and innovation in her creative works that have enhanced the perception of women through the medium of television.{{cite web |url=http://wif.org/past-recipients |title=Past Recipients |publisher=Wif.org |date= |accessdate=2013-02-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/614ten37o?url=http://wif.org/past-recipients |archivedate=2011-08-20 |df= }} [[File:Debra Messing at the 2009 Tribeca Film Festival.jpg|thumb|Messing at the Vanity Fair Party to kick off the 8th Annual Tribeca Film Festival in 2009]] She also starred in the television miniseries ''[[The Starter Wife (miniseries)|The Starter Wife]]'' (2007), which was nominated for ten [[Emmy Award]]s, including one for Messing for [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actress - Miniseries or a Movie|Outstanding Lead Actress in a Miniseries or Movie]]. In 2008, Messing reprised her role as Molly Kagan in the television series ''[[The Starter Wife (TV series)|The Starter Wife]]'', consisting of 10 episodes.[https://tv.yahoo.com/the-starter-wife/show/39277/news/urn:newsml:tv.reuters.com:20071017:messing_dc__ER] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071023064143/http://tv.yahoo.com/the-starter-wife/show/39277/news/urn%3Anewsml%3Atv.reuters.com%3A20071017%3Amessing_dc__ER|date=October 23, 2007}} In early 2010, Messing starred in the ABC comedy pilot ''Wright vs. Wrong'' for the 2010–2011 primetime season, but the pilot was not picked up by ABC.{{cite web|title=Wright vs. Wrong| url =http://login.vnuemedia.com/hr/content_display/television/news/e3i5d08aae04387a06d43a41edbb441b040|date = 2009-04-20 | accessdate =2009-05-24}} [http://www.tvguide.com/News/Cheryl-Hines-Carrie-1016636.aspx Wright vs. Wrong] In July 2011, Messing was ranked no. 22 on the [[TV Guide Network]] special, ''Funniest Women on TV''.{{Cite AV media | title = Funniest Women on TV | url = https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1990233/?ref_=fn_tt_tt_1 | credits = | publisher = [[TV Guide Network]] | date = July 3, 2011}} In February 2011, it was announced that Messing would star in a new NBC musical pilot called ''[[Smash (TV series)|Smash]]'' for the 2011–2012 primetime season.{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/News/Debra-Messing-NBC-1028963.aspx |title=Debra Messing to Headline NBC's Musical Pilot - Today's News: Our Take |publisher=TVGuide.com |date=2011-02-07 |accessdate=2013-02-20}} In May 2011, it was reported that [[NBC]] picked up the show as a series for the 2011-2012 season.{{cite web|last=Andreeva |first=Nellie |url=http://www.deadline.com/2011/05/nbc-picks-up-whitney-cummings-comedy-pilot-to-series-more-coming/ |title=May 11, 2011: "NBC Picks Up Whitney Cummings & Emily Spivey Pilots, 'Smash' & 'Prime Suspect'" |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |date= |accessdate=2013-02-20}} The show premiered on February 6, 2012. The show was later renewed for a second season. After two seasons, it was cancelled.{{cite news|title=It's Curtains: NBC Officially Cancels Smash|url=http://tvline.com/2013/05/10/smash-cancelled-nbc/|accessdate=September 8, 2013|newspaper=[[TVline]]|date=May 10, 2013}} Messing appeared with [[Green Day]] singer [[Billie Joe Armstrong]] and [[Leighton Meester]] in [[Frank Whaley]]'s drama film ''[[Like Sunday, Like Rain]]'' in 2014. For her performance, Debra won the 2014 Best Actress Award at The Williamsburg Independent Film Festival{{Cite web|url=http://www.willfilm.org/Winners|title=2014 Winners|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}. She made her [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] debut in [[John Patrick Shanley]]'s play ''[[Outside Mullingar]]'' alongside [[Tony Award]] winner [[Brían F. O'Byrne]], which began previews at the [[Samuel J. Friedman Theatre]] on January 3, 2014.{{cite web|first=Brandon|last=Voss|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140104211047/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/186068-Gracing-Broadway-mdash-Debra-Messing-Returns-to-the-Stage-in-MTCs-Outside-Mullingar?tsrc=hph|title=Gracing Broadway — Debra Messing Returns to the Stage in MTC's 'Outside Mullingar' |work=[[Playbill (magazine)|Playbill]]|location=New York City|date=January 4, 2014|accessdate=March 7, 2018}} ''Outside Mullingar'' was nominated for Best Play for the 2014 (68th Annual) Tony Awards. Messing starred in ''[[The Mysteries of Laura]]'', a police procedural television show that premiered in September 2014. The series lasted for two seasons and ended in 2016. Messing was also cast as Marjorie Houseman in the [[Dirty Dancing (2017 film)|television remake]] of the 1987 film, ''[[Dirty Dancing]]''. It aired on ABC in May 2017.{{cite web|first=Nellie|last=Andreeva|title='Dirty Dancing' ABC Remake Casts Debra Messing, Gets Firm Green Light|url=http://deadline.com/2016/01/dirty-dancing-abc-remake-debra-messing-cast-green-light-1201683225/|website=Deadline Hollywood|publisher=Penske Business Media, LLC|location=New York City|date=January 14, 2016|accessdate=March 19, 2016}} She currently stars as Grace Adler in the revival of ''Will & Grace'' on NBC. ==Personal life== Messing met [[Daniel Zelman]], an actor and screenwriter, on their first day as graduate students at [[New York University]] in 1990. They were married on September 3, 2000, and lived in [[Manhattan]]. On April 7, 2004, Messing gave birth to their son, Roman Walker Zelman.{{cite web|url=http://www.superiorpics.com/debra_messing/ |title=The Debra Messing Picture Pages |publisher=Superiorpics.com |date= |accessdate=2010-04-07}} In December 2011, she and her husband separated after 11 years of marriage.{{cite web |first= Natalie |last=Finn |url= http://www.eonline.com/news/finished_wife_debra_messing_husband/282031 |title= The Finished Wife: Debra Messing and Husband Separate |work= E! Online |publisher= eonline.com}} Messing filed for divorce on June 5, 2012.{{cite web |first=Dahvi |last=Shira |url= http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20601394,00.html |title= Debra Messing Files for Divorce |publisher= [[People (magazine)|People]] |location= Des Moines, Iowa|date=June 5, 2012|accessdate=March 7, 2018}} The divorce was officially completed on March 1, 2016.{{cite news|title=Judge ends Debra Messing's marriage to writer-producer |url=http://www.charlotteobserver.com/entertainment/tv/article63641017.html |agency=[[Associated Press]] |work=[[The Charlotte Observer]]|publisher=[[McClatchy Company]]|location=Sacramento, California|date=March 2, 2016 |accessdate=March 3, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160307184903/http://www.charlotteobserver.com/entertainment/tv/article63641017.html |archivedate=March 7, 2016 |df= }} Messing dated her ''Smash'' co-star [[Will Chase]] from the end of 2011 to October 2014.{{cite web|first=Melody|last=Chiu|title=Debra Messing and Will Chase Split|url=http://www.people.com/article/debra-messing-will-chase-break-up|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|publisher=[[Meredith Corporation]]|location=Des Moines, Iowa|date=October 27, 2014|accessdate=March 7, 2018}} ==Filmography== ===Film=== {| class = "wikitable sortable" |- ! Year ! Title ! Role ! class = "unsortable" | Notes |- |1995 |''{{sortname|A|Walk in the Clouds}}'' |Betty Sutton | |- |1997 |''[[McHale's Navy (1997 film)|McHale's Navy]]'' |Lt. Penelope Carpenter | |- |1998 |''[[Celebrity (film)|Celebrity]]'' |TV reporter | |- |1999 |''[[Jesus (1999 film)|Jesus]]'' |[[Mary Magdalene]] | |- |2002 |''{{sortname|The|Mothman Prophecies|The Mothman Prophecies (film)}}'' |Mary Klein | |- |2002 |''[[Hollywood Ending]]'' |Lori | |- |2004 |''[[Along Came Polly]]'' |Lisa Kramer | |- |2004 |''[[Garfield (film)|Garfield]]'' |Arlene | Voice only |- |2005 |''{{sortname|The|Wedding Date}}'' |Kat Ellis | |- |2006 |''[[Open Season (2006 film)|Open Season]]'' |[[Beth (Open Season)|Beth]] |Voice only |- |2007 |''[[Purple Violets]]'' |Kate Scott | |- |2007 |''[[Lucky You (film)|Lucky You]]'' |Suzanne Offer | |- |2008 |''{{sortname|The|Women|The Women (2008 film)}}'' |Edie Cohen | |- |2008 |''[[Nothing like the Holidays]]'' |Sarah Rodriguez | |- |2014 |''[[Like Sunday, Like Rain]]'' |Barbara | |- |2018 |''[[Searching (film)|Searching]]'' |Detective Rosemary Vick | |} ===Television=== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width: 100%;" |- ! Year ! Title ! Role ! Notes |- |1994–1995 |''[[NYPD Blue]]'' |Dana Abandando |3 episodes |- |1995 |''[[Partners (1995 TV series)|Partners]]'' |Stacey |1 episode |- |1995–1997 |''[[Ned & Stacey]]'' |Stacey Colbert | 46 episodes |- |1996–1997 |''[[Seinfeld]]'' |Beth Lookner |2 episodes |- |1998 |''[[Prey (TV series)|Prey]]'' |Dr. Sloan Parker | 13 episodes |- |1998–2006,
2017–present |''[[Will & Grace]]'' |[[Grace Adler]] |Main role; 200 episodes |- |2002 |''[[King of the Hill]]'' |Mrs. Hilgren-Bronson |1 episode |- |2007–08 |''[[The Starter Wife (TV series)|The Starter Wife]]'' |Molly Kagan |10 episodes |- |2009 |''[[Sesame Street]]'' |Herself |1 episode |- |2011 |''[[Law & Order: Special Victims Unit]]'' |Alicia Harding |1 episode |- |2012–13 |''[[Smash (TV series)|Smash]]'' |[[Characters of Smash#Julia Houston|Julia Houston]] |32 episodes |- |2012 |''[[Project Runway]]'' |Herself/Guest judge |[[Project Runway (season 10)|Season 10]], Episode: "I Get a Kick Out of Fashion" |- |2014–16 |''[[The Mysteries of Laura]]'' |Detective Laura Diamond |Lead role, 38 episodes |- |2015 |''[[Jeopardy!]]'' |Herself |4 episodes |- |2016 |''[[Match Game]]'' |Herself |1 episode |- |2016 |''[[Nightcap (2016 TV series)|Nightcap]]'' |Herself |1 episode |- |2017 |''[[Dirty Dancing (2017 film)|Dirty Dancing]]'' |Marjorie Houseman |Television film |} ==Awards and nominations== Messing's most honored role is as [[Grace Adler]] on ''[[Will & Grace]]'' earning the actress six [[Golden Globe Award|Golden Globe award]] nominations for [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Television Series Musical or Comedy|Best Lead Actress in a Television Series - Comedy or Musical]], five [[Primetime Emmy Award|Primetime Emmy award]] nominations for [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actress in a Comedy Series|Outstanding Lead Actress in a Comedy Series]]; one of which she won in 2006, and seven [[Screen Actors Guild Award|Screen Actors Guild award]] nominations; two for [[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Female Actor in a Comedy Series|Outstanding Performance by a Female Actor in a Comedy Series]], and five for [[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by an Ensemble in a Comedy Series|Outstanding Performance by an Ensemble in a Comedy Series]] - winning one in 2001. {| class="wikitable" !Year !Title !Accolade !Results |- | rowspan="4" |1999 | rowspan="38" |''[[Will & Grace]]'' |Online Film & Television Association award, Best Lead Actress in a New Comedy Series |{{Nominated}} |- |Online Film & Television Association award, Best Lead Actress in a Comedy Series |{{Nominated}} |- |Online Film & Television Association award, Best Ensemble in a Comedy Series (shared with [[Eric McCormack]], [[Sean Hayes (actor)|Sean Hayes]], [[Megan Mullally]]) |{{Nominated}} |- |[[Viewers for Quality Television|Viewers for Quality Television award, Best Lead Actress in a Quality Comedy Series]] |{{Nominated}} |- | rowspan="6" |2000 |[[American Comedy Awards|American Comedy award, Funniest Lead Female Performer in Network, Cable or Syndication]] |{{Nominated}} |- |[[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Television Series Musical or Comedy|Golden Globe award, Best Lead Actress in a Television Series - Comedy or Musical]] |{{Nominated}} |- |Online Film & Television Association award, Best Lead Actress in a Comedy Series |{{Nominated}} |- |Online Film & Television Association award, Best Ensemble in a Comedy Series (shared with Eric McCormack, Sean Hayes, Megan Mullally) |{{WON}} |- |[[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actress in a Comedy Series|Primetime Emmy award, Outstanding Lead Actress in a Comedy Series]] |{{Nominated}} |- |[[Viewers for Quality Television|Viewers for Quality Television award, Best Lead Actress in a Quality Comedy Series]] |{{Nominated}} |- | rowspan="9" |2001 |[[American Comedy Awards|American Comedy award, Funniest Lead Female Performer in a Network, Cable or Syndication]] |{{Nominated}} |- |[[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Television Series Musical or Comedy|Golden Globe award, Best Lead Actress in a Television Series - Comedy or Musical]] |{{Nominated}} |- |Online Film & Television Association award, Best Lead Actress in a Comedy Series |{{Nominated}} |- |Online Film & Television Association award, Best Ensemble in a Comedy Series (shared with Eric McCormack, Sean Hayes, Megan Mullally) |{{WON}} |- |[[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actress in a Limited Series or Movie|Primetime Emmy award, Outstanding Lead Actress in a Comedy Series]] |{{Nominated}} |- |[[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Female Actor in a Comedy Series|Screen Actors Guild award, Outstanding Performance by a Female Actor in a Comedy Series]] |{{Nominated}} |- |[[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by an Ensemble in a Comedy Series|Screen Actors Guild award, Outstanding Performance by an Ensemble in a Comedy Series]] (shared with Eric McCormack, Sean Hayes, Megan Mullally) |{{WON}} |- |[[Teen Choice Award for Choice TV Actress Comedy|Teen Choice award, Choice TV Actress - Comedy or Musical]] |{{WON}} |- |[[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by an Ensemble in a Comedy Series|Screen Actors Guild award, Outstanding Performance by an Ensemble in a Comedy Series]] (shared with Eric McCormack, Sean Hayes, Megan Mullally) |{{Nominated}} |- |[[Teen Choice Award for Choice TV Actress Comedy|Teen Choice award, Choice TV Actress - Comedy]] |{{Nominated}} |- | rowspan="5" |2003 |[[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Television Series Musical or Comedy|Golden Globe award, Best Lead Actress in a Television Series - Comedy or Musical]] |{{Nominated}} |- |Online Film & Television Association award, Best Lead Actress in a Comedy Series |{{Nominated}} |- |[[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actress in a Limited Series or Movie|Primetime Emmy award, Outstanding Lead Actress in a Comedy Series]] |{{WON}} |- |[[Satellite Award for Best Actress – Television Series Musical or Comedy|Satellite award, Best Lead Actress in a Series - Comedy or Musical]] |{{WON}} |- |[[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by an Ensemble in a Comedy Series|Screen Actors Guild award, Outstanding Performance by an Ensemble in a Comedy Series]] (shared with Eric McCormack, Sean Hayes, Megan Mullally) |{{Nominated}} |- | rowspan="5" |2004 |[[Gold Derby Awards|Gold Derby award, Best Lead Actress in a Comedy Series]] |{{Nominated}} |- |[[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Television Series Musical or Comedy|Golden Globe award, Best Lead Actress in a Television Series - Comedy or Musical]] |{{Nominated}} |- |[[Satellite Award for Best Actress – Television Series Musical or Comedy|Satellite award, Best Lead Actress in a Series - Comedy or Musical]] |{{Nominated}} |- |[[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Female Actor in a Comedy Series|Screen Actors Guild award, Outstanding Performance by a Female Actor in a Comedy Series]] |{{Nominated}} |- |[[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by an Ensemble in a Comedy Series|Screen Actors Guild award, Outstanding Performance by an Ensemble in a Comedy Series]] (shared with Eric McCormack, Sean Hayes, Megan Mullally) |{{Nominated}} |- | rowspan="5" |2005 |[[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Television Series Musical or Comedy|Golden Globe award, Best Lead Actress in a Television Series - Comedy or Musical]] |{{Nominated}} |- |[[People's Choice Awards|People's Choice award, Favorite Female Television Star]] |{{Nominated}} |- ! |[[People's Choice Awards|People's Choice award, Favorite Funny Female Star]] |{{Nominated}} |- |''[[Will & Grace]]'' |[[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by an Ensemble in a Comedy Series|Screen Actors Guild award, Outstanding Performance by an Ensemble in a Comedy Series]] (shared with Eric McCormack, Sean Hayes, Megan Mullally) |{{Nominated}} |- ! |[[Women in Film Crystal + Lucy Awards|Women in Film Crystal + Lucy award, Lucy award]] |{{WON}} |- | rowspan="3" |2006 | rowspan="3" |''[[Will & Grace]]'' |Online Film & Television Association award, Best Lead Actress in a Comedy Series |{{WON}} |- |[[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actress in a Limited Series or Movie|Primetime Emmy award, Outstanding Lead Actress in a Comedy Series]] |{{Nominated}} |- |[[Teen Choice Award for Choice TV Actress Comedy|Teen Choice award, Choice TV Actress -
